text: The STEADY FOOTFALL OF A WOMAN’s BOOTS, sinking in wet sand- The RISE and FALL of a WOMAN’s breath- MRS GEORGE WHARTON ROBINSON aka ‘NELLY’, head down consum by thought, etching a line across the sand, like charcoal on paper until- NELLY stops looking out at the endless grey Margate coastline beyond, eyes dark and lost in some deep trouble distraction, a sense she has walked as far as the landsca will let her- Heart beating, chest rising, she stands until- She turns, head down, once more walking, as she picks up her pace- The swoop and call of gulls, skimming the pier, overhead. INT. SCHOOL HALL. SCHOOLHOUSE. MARGATE. DAY. 1885.

A school hall- On a raised stage, a YOUNG SCHOOL BOY in fake moustache dressed as a waiter, stands in waiting. Two more SCHOOLBOYS, dressed in climbing costumes, sit at a cafe table close by. A back cloth of the Swiss Alps strung up behind. A young male teacher MR LAMBOURNE [late 20's] hovers distracted, clearly trying to organise an errant backstage. In the wings just visible, PROP MAKERS and STAGE MANAGERS adjust collars on SCHOOLBOY ACTORS; An angelic LION [6 yr waits with OTHERS, bored and tired in floormop wig and painted nose, yawning as he peeks out to the auditorium beyond to see- REVEREND WILLIAM BENHAM [mid 50’s] sits, silently waiting in the makeshift stalls, reading through a playscript entitled- No Thoroughfare: A Drama in Five Acts by Charles Dickens and Wilkie Collins. Beyond a small orchestra of SCHOOLBOYS just visible ina makeshift orchestra pit; a JOLLY SCHOOLBOY PERCUSSIONIST tightens a nut on a wide drum. A TEENAGE VIOLINIST waxes the strings on a viola, a SCHOOLBOY OBOIST and PIANIST quietly tune up, looking to the clock overhead. The SENSE OF TIME TICKING ON-
Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 2.
MR GEORGE WHARTON[early 30's] headmaster, clergyman and husband, just visible escorting a PORTLY PARENT along a distant corridor.

Here is the theatre. The boys always perform a short play at the end of term, highly popular with the parents. Theatre is an abiding interest of my wife’s. Which of course I delight in! He smiles at BENHAM, a shared look of quizzical concern, clock ticking overhead.
Is she still not here? BENHAM shrugs, smiles benignly.

Mr and Mrs Featherstone may I introduce Mr Benham. Mr Benham is invaluable to the school. He assists my wife with penny readings and other charitable events. You will often find them in corners plotting their next money raising venture. The CAST, ORCHESTRA and BENHAM wait on-
(moving on) Shall we move on?
NELLY clambering over sandy dune seeing a small town in t distance. She hurries on.
NELLY ascends a small path in the town. She walks briskly towards a schoolhouse and enters.
MARY, the maid carrying a tray with oil lamps on passing GEORGE and the PORTLY PARENT heading towards the study-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 3.

Mary, tea if you please. MARY quietly disgruntled, slides the tray down, turning to head back to the kitchen. A shadowy figure just visible through the glass, NELLY on the approach- The SWING OF THE FRONT DOOR open, NELLY hurriedly pulling off hat and scarf, just seeing GEORGE, closing the door o his study-
(hushed) Mr Benham has been here since-
(nods ) Yes..Yes..I am so sorry.
Mr Lambourne has been organising the boys as best he can.
I lost all sense of time. NELLY hurrying along the corridor, a sense of activity as she passes-—
(in passing) Careful with those corners, Langan- A SCHOOLBOY nods, carrying a huge piece of scenery with ANOTHER BOY follow NELLY through a distant door into- INT. SCHOOLHALL. MARGATE. DAY. 1885.
And at once, NELLY is on- The SCHOOLBOYS smile with relief on seeing-
Mr Benham I am so sorry..I am here..I am here. NELLY looking to the SCHOOLBOYS with a reassuring smile a a smile of thanks to LAMBOURNE.
(to all) Forgive me. Dear Boys. NELLY, energy infectious, lights up the room as she enter  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 4.
Let’s go from the third act. Mr Benham must not see all our tricks quite yet or there will be nothing left to show him tomorrow.
It is cold outside.
It is. But it clears the mind.
It does. It does. BENHAM clutches a couple of volumes of DICKENS- Great Expectations and David Copperfield.
It would be good to decide on the readings before the end of term.
Yes..Yes of course..I am happy to consider your suggestions. Maybe later? NELLY wavers, nods, smiles, turning her attention back to the boys.
Laurenson? Tanner? Are we ready? Good. NELLY smiles at the SCHOOLBOY ACTORS, with encouragement. She nods to MR LAMBOURNE.
Mr Lambourne, are you happy with everything as it is? LAMBOURNE nods.
(eyeing WAITER) The moustaches works well, I think. SUDDENLY GEOFFREY WHARTON ROBINSON[6yrs] the angelic lion peers from behind the wings. NELLY, eyes him

No Geoffrey, dear. Not yet. You come in on the final line. (hushed) We don’t want to scare Mr Benham just yet or he may not return.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 5. GEOFFREY nods, NELLY smiles, hurrying to take her place next to BENHAM.
I recall no lion in Mr Dickens and Mr Collins Play, Mrs Wharton Robinson.
A little dramatic licence. I am confident that Mr Dickens would have let it pass- NELLY deflects, with a smile.
Shall we begin? NELLY nods to an OLD STAGE MANAGER.

Yates, would you drop the backing. The OLD STAGE MANAGER nods, hurrying to drop a scenery cl revealing a mountain landscape. The SCHOOLBOYS begin a short musical introduction. MR LAMBOURNE indicates the pace with a nod of his head.
Well, my lads, the day is breaking at last. NELLY is up at once-
..-No..the day has broken,Hadley. On BENHAM noticing-
Lets get it right. The EARNEST SCHOOLBOY MOUNTAINEER nods.

Well, my lads the day has broken- NELLY consoled, offers a nod and we are away as the SCENE BREAKS into life on the stage, as the SCHOOLBOY WAITER se coffee to the SCHOOLBOY MOUNTAINEERS, lost in earnest act SCHOOL BOY 1 (CONT’D) What do you say to the weather, now?
I say the weather will do.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 5A.
I say doubtful!
I say - bad!  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 6. NELLY’s hand silently stills the absent tap of an ERRANT SCHOOLBOY’s foot against his chair as he sits ina makeshift prompt box close by.
(shouting out) A little louder if you please John. The SCHOOL CONDUCTOR NODS to a KEEN VIOLINIST, BOW AT THE

I can see for myself that there's a storm coming. THEN he nods to a LARGE SCHOOLBOY who rattles a metal sto sheet, whilst the JOLLY PERCUSSIONIST turns a wind drum, and a THIRD SCHOOLBOY SHIFTS a TIN OF PEAS, building in momentum like icy drops of sleeting rain, all just visibl in the makeshift wings. SCHOOL BOY 2 (CONT’D) I smell the snow- The RISING SOUNDS of percussive storm LOUDER NOW- SCHOOL BOY 2 (CONT’D) ...-I feel the hurricane, in the air. TWO SCHOOLBOY MOUNTAINEERS cross the stage, joining the cafe scene
Well are you ready at last? The BACK AND FORTH OF THE METAL STORM TRAY RATTLING, THE

location: CARRIAGE. TRAIN. NEAR STAPLEHURST. KENT. DAY. 1865.

text: The TEARING STEADY RHYTHM OF TRAIN WHEELS AGAINST STEEL A
The STREAK of countryside, FLEETING and ABSTRACTED, a BLU of light and colour beyond.
I am sick and weary of all this delay Then just visible in the glass, NELLY[mid 20's] reflectio indistinct yet rippling in the glass-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 7.
You hear what my friend says? Do you cross the mountain with us or not?

NELLY, seemingly lost in watching the play, oblivious to BENHAM'’s brief gaze, quietly observant, noting little to give away her state of distraction bar the steam of her w boots and the sense that her mind is always elsewhere-

Fair weather or foul, I have no time to lose. And I am for pushing on- But still BENHAM clocks it, looking back, resuming watchi The SCHOOL BOY MOUTAINEERS climbing a mountainous pile of plaster and cardboard Alp. The endless icy landscape beyo and SWIRL of the PERCUSSIVE STORM DEAFENING IN THE
A YOUNG PERCUSSIONIST SWILLS peas in a tin tray, creating noise of falling rain. It builds and builds- ALL carrying NELLY far away, deep within her mind-

location: STREET. FREE TRADE HALL. MANCHESTER. 1857. DAY. 8

text: The impressive Manchester Free Trade hall looming above- The TURN of WHEELS over wet cobbles-— The STEAMING FLANK OF HORSES, HOOVES TREADING WET COBBLES

head_text.subj: THEY PULL A CARRIAGE TO A STILL-

text: FINGERS REACHING UP to UNFASTEN a carriage door, CHARLEY DICKENS [18 yrs] stands holding an umbrella waiting- A young NELLY [18 yrs] steps down from the carriage to be greeted by CHARLEY, holding up the umbrella, trying to sh her from the pouring rain.

(holding out a hand) Miss Ellen, welcome. I am Charley Dickens. Welcome to Manchester. NELLY smiles, suddenly a glove clasped in her hand falls the ground. CHARLEY at once bends down picks it up.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 8.
Thank you.. Behind NELLY, MRS FRANCES TERNAN [late 40’s] NELLY’s moth bright, lively woman peering out into the grey of Manches life.
Welcome..Welcome..Mrs Ternan.
Charley, thank you. So wet.
Yes, do be careful. MARIA TERNAN [20 yrs] NELLY’s sister smiling clutching a box-
Miss Maria. Come inside..Come inside.. The SWAY of CRINOLINE skimming the rainy pavements-

My father is waiting. The others are already here. What a day! NELLY, MRS TERNAN guided by CHARLEY towards the entrance the Free Trade hall passing a poster advertising-— The Frozen Deep by Mr. Wilkie Collins. Under the manageme of Mr. Charles Dickens clearly visible on a billboard overhead-
Nelly, look- MARIA beaming, eyes searching the poster, at last finding Frances Ternan, Miss Maria Ternan, Miss Ellen Ternan. NEL MARIA and MRS TERNAN peering at the poster with quiet awe
Yes, there we are.

The print is a little small, but no matter. CHARLEY beyond waiting. MRS TERNAN ushering MARIA and NELLY inside. Their bonnets and skirts a flash of colour against the grey of Manchester life all around-  10 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 9.

location: CORRIDOR. FREE TRADE HALL. MANCHESTER. 1857. DAY. 9

text: CHARLEY leading the trio of women along an impressive woo lined corridor. Chairs stacked either side. He leads them through into-

location: MAIN HALL. FREE TRADE HALL. MANCHESTER. 1857. DAY 10

text: The opulent and magnificent interior of the Free Trade Hall- Paintings of the Kings and Queens of England flank one si of the wall as CHARLEY leads them towards- A beautiful theatre in the final moments of construction the far end of the vast hall. CARPENTERS, STAGE MANAGEMEN GASLIGHT ENGINEERS working around the distant figure of CHARLES DICKENS [mid 40’s] lost in directing the STAGE HA and STAGE MANAGEMENT in placing the scenery on the stage.

Yes..Yes..If we could have the flat over there..We need to create as much space as possible. .We’1l probably have to bring everyting to the left..What worked at Tavistock house will seem lost here..Our set looks like a toy theatre if we do not- CHARLEY leading NELLY, MRS TERNAN and MARIA towards the s

Father- DICKENS turns and at once he is lost behind a huge flat o painted rocks being manoeuvered into place on the stage. the scenery has past, he is revealed. He jumps down from stage, springing across the hall, smiling, arms outstretc delighting in their arrival-
At last we have a full company! Mrs Ternan welcome.
Mr Dickens. (surveying theatre) What a beautiful theatre you have built for us.
We have tried. I am glad. Welcome Miss Maria..A good journey I hope?  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 10.
Yes..Yes..Mr Dickens. Thank you.
It was quite comfortable.
Good. Good. And you must be Miss Ellen Ternan. DICKENS stops, mid way through shaking their hands, pausi on NELLY, with a smile.
You’ve met my eldest son Charley of course.
Yes..yes..He very kindly rescued my glove.
Ah, the gallant chevalier! DICKENS grips CHARLEY’s shoulder in passing, turning to present them to the MEMBERS of the COMPANY-
Ladies and gentleman may we welcome our newcomer, Miss Ellen who is helping us in our hour of need. (to NELLY) We wish your sister Frances well. Is it the Haymarket or Phoenix we have lost her to?
The Haymarket. She is so sad not to be here.
But Nelly will give you a wonderful performance-
I have no doubt. DICKENS smiles, the MEMBERS of the company on the approac welcoming. DICKENS, in a spiral of energy, enthusiastical enjoying the performance of these introductions-—
Now Maria, Mrs Ternan you know everyone from our previous rehearsals..  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 11.
Yes..Yes..I remember..Some familiar faces. I remember.
Miss Ellen may I introduce you to our family of actors- MR EGG[early 40’s]MR LEMON [mid 40’s] and MISS SABINE [ea 30’s]smiling and shaking hands, surrounding MRS TERNAN, N and MARIA.
Mr Lemon, Mr Egg, Miss Sabine...Mr Berger, our brilliant young composer-— MR BERGER [mid 20’s] amongst the SWELL of welcoming actor
Mr Evans, Mr Piggot..I would like to introduce you to our author Mr Collins- DICKENS looks beyond, eyes searching with wry irritation-

But as ever he is late..And of course some of my own family- MAMEY DICKENS [17 yrs] and KATEY DICKENS [16 yrs] DICKENS eldest daughters and GEORGINA HOGARTH [early/mid 30's] CATHERINE’s SISTER close by-

My daughters Mamey, Katey and my sister in law Miss Georgina Hogarth. And here is- DICKENS rounding up four boys FRANK [13 yrs], ALFRED[12 y SYDNEY [10 yrs] HENRY DICKENS [8 yrs] tapping their heads with percussive aplomb on every name-

Frank- (tap) Alfred- (tap) Sydney- (tap) Henry.... (tap) Where is youngest boy-? EDWARD ‘PLORN’ DICKENS [5 yrs] nervously peers out from behind DICKENS, DICKENS mock searching behind his coat ta  11 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 12.
Plorn. Don’t hide there. DICKENS at once scoops PLORN up in his arms, smiling. NEL watching enchanted, the names and faces already a blur.
And that is it..I think..And..of course, my wife- Beyond, CATHERINE DICKENS [early 40’s] DICKENS’ wife, hea and swollen seated someway off. NELLY looks over, their e briefly meeting.
Now I suggest maybe in half an hour..Is that enough time ladies to settle your bonnets..? - I would like to rehearse- DICKENS just seeing-
..-but without our author- WILKIE COLLINS[mid 30’s] DICKENS colleague and friend run towards him, from across the hall, tripping over his bags with fashionable aplomb-
Mr Collins..Who is at last here! Why is it I am waiting for you, Wilkie? Why must you always be late? COLLINS in smiling greeting, embracing DICKENS-
Because it irritates you, Charles, and it amuses me to see you in bad temper!

location: STAGE. FREE TRADE HALL. LONDON. 1857. DAY. 11

text: The SET and THEATRE now fully installed. A few STAGE HAND finishing off small bits of carpentry and adjusting set. set now lit with oil lamps. The ACTORS wait on stage, finding their positions. NELLY amongst them, ushered by MRS TERNAN into place. Downstage, to one side, DICKENS and WILKIE in whispered debate-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 13.
I cannot see a scene we can afford to lose, Charles. DICKENS pen in hand, mapping out potential cuts on a page the script-

But it is too long. And it will bore if it is too long. It was too long in London and it will be too long in Manchester. Though it pains me... Wilkie- DICKENS hands the script back to COLLINS, offering him a at his suggested cuts, his gaze direct.
Cut.Cut.Cut. COLLINS throws his hands up exasperated but concedes, sco ferociously through the text with his pencil.
It is done! It is done! (hushed) You may tell Mr Egg he has lost his last soliloquy.
(hushed) You must do it. As author I shall not deny you that.
You are insufferable. DICKENS scribbles more on the script, then hands it once back to COLLINS.
And here..And here..
Butcher! DICKENS smiles, walks to centre stage to address the comp of ACTORS-
Now everyone please be careful.- Our little theatre is not yet complete- DICKENS nods to MR STANFIELD giving a finishing touch to set, paintbrush in hand.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 14.

And as we are rehearsing Miss Ellen in today let us be considerate. I am keen to review the last act, just the final entry of Wardour and Aldersly so places friends. (directing MARIA) Maria, if we could have you over there. DICKENS gently positions MARIA, moving back across the stage-
And-? DICKENS’ eyes graze over NELLY mildly lost, awaiting direction.
We have the ladies in a group over here. Miss Ellen..Mrs Ternan.
Just over here, Nelly dearest. Mr Dickens may I suggest the women are positioned a little further upstage?
Yes..Let us have you here.
Thank you. MRS TERNAN nods to NELLY to follow her, taking their positions in a small cluster close by.
Should I stand a little wider?
Yes, very good, Maria..But not too far, for it is your face and not mine that will be holding the attention of our audience I feel sure.
Where’s Collins? COLLINS looks up, from his script, both actor and writer, hurrying onto the stage.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 15.
I will need you standing close to the rear if I am to carry you in, Wilkie. You're ready?

(hurrying off) No..Yes..Yes. COLLINS disappears behind a flat, then puts his head back around- COLLINS (CONT’D) Should you not come? I cannot carry myself. NELLY smiles, enjoying the banter as DICKENS disappears o to the side of the wings.

Of course..yes..Yes. (pointing to CHARLEY) Charley, there, relax the arms. A little less stiff. CHARLEY nods, taking his place, DICKENS disappearing once more off stage. MUTTERINGS and THEN- NELLY looking down at her part on sides of paper in her h
(aside to MRS TERNAN) Do I speak after the gun? SUDDENLY DICKENS enters carrying COLLINS -
Frank!..Frank!! MARIA raises her hands to her face, looking suitably alarmed.
Then my line...Saved, Saved for you!
Don’t you put me down here? DICKENS releases COLLINS, MARIA now cradling COLLINS in her arms.
He's footsore and weary, Clara. But I have saved him..And so on..and so on..  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 16. DICKENS gestures for MR LEMON to step forward.
(pointing) Yes, there very good. Then your line Wilkie- COLLINS looks up as all crowd around him.
Where is Wardour?! Help him! Never mind me! DICKENS already on the floor now, in dying pose.
(to MR LEMON) Mark, this is when you see me. MR LEMON falls at DICKENS feet.
Wardour! Dear Wardour! Old friend whom I have wronged, remember and forgive me.
Very good. You are forgiven.
Then the scene plays as is. DICKENS directing from his dying pose.

Do not be afraid to project. We have over 2,000 seats. (shouting out) Catherine, do say if you cannot hear us. CATHERINE just visible perched on a seat looks up, not listening, somewhat bemused. CLOSE by her sister GEORGINA and the DICKENS CHILDREN, watching appreciatively.
(distracted) What?
(calling back) We can hear you very well, Charles.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 17.
Very good. Everyone speak up. Maria, you take me in your arms.
Richard, dear Richard, look at your old playmate.
Then music-— MR BERGER at the piano to the side of the stage, begins t play-

Not yet Berger. I am just marking through the cues... which lasts until the curtain has fallen by which time I am nearly dead. Then we kiss. Then gun. BANG! Then- (looking to NELLY) Epilogue-? NELLY looks up, in waiting-
Epilogue. NELLY walks forward a little, clutching a few pages of script.

This is a tale of woe. This is a tale of sorrow. A love denied. A love restored to live beyond tomorrow. Lest we think silence is the place to hide a heavy heart, remember to love and be loved is life itself. Without which we are nought. NELLY quietly captivating, a little nervous yet oddly touching, DICKENS momentarily lost until-
(hushed aside) Maybe a little louder, Nelly. DICKENS turns, addresses all-

The curtain closes. Loud applause. Yet audible the crying of 2,000. Bravo. Bravo. I suggest a full dress rehearsal in two hours time. Thank you gentleman-  12 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 18. DICKENS eyes flick to NELLY.
Thank you ladies. The COMPANY of ACTORS already dissolving, lost in their conversation as they head off to dressing rooms and costu fittings.
Oh Charles, your last speech I think could benefit from cutting.
You think so?
I do.
(deflecting) Catherine-? CATHERINE looks up barely listening.
Shall we discuss it?
Yes. Later. COLLINS, shakes his head, concedes. DICKENS reaches for a small flask of brandy in his coat pocket, swigs, sees NEL alone, the Arctic landscape behind.
(almost to himself) She has something. COLLINS noting DICKENS quiet distraction, looking on. NEL disappearing into the scenery of the Frozen Deep.

location: ONSTAGE. FREE TRADE HALL. MANCHESTER.1857. NIGHT. 12

text: A weeping MARIA, her face stained with tears, DICKENS in arms, swathed in rags, beard, grey and powdery, dying in MARIA’s arms, illuminated on stage by a row of lit gaslig as the play comes to its end. MR LEMON kneels down close to a dying DICKENS as he lies MARIA’s arms, her body shuddering with tears. DICKENS reaches out a hand, patting MR LEMON’s arm in fin embrace.  13 14 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 19.
Come nearer! My mind clears, but my eyes grow dim. You will remember me kindly for Frank's sake? Poor Frank! Why does he hide his face? MR EGG looks away, his face streaming with tears.
Is he crying? Just seen beyond in the wings, some of the ACTORS and STAGEHANDS watching, NELLY amongst them, all held in the absolute moment, NELLY watching DICKENS with a quiet intensity-

Nearer Clara - I want to look my last at you. My sister, Clara! Kiss me Sister, kiss me before I die. MARIA kisses DICKENS- Just visible in the wings, a STAGE HAND sets light to gunpowder, mimicking the blast of a ships gun/cannon. NELLY, lost in DICKENS’ performance, oblivious to the curtain sweeping closed-
(urgent/hushed in passing) Nelly..Nelly.. NELLY hurries on stage, to deliver her epilogue.

DICKENS, arms outstretched at the front of the stage, leading his cast in triumphant encore- MARIA flushed and beaming, DICKENS presenting her centre stage- NELLY looking on, bashfully happy. She sees DICKENS smiling at her down the line.

head_text.subj: FINGERS BANG, BANG AND BANG AGAIN BASHING OUT IMPROMPTU

text: No, No I am sorry, it is not enough that we should play before these mere mortals... DICKENS smiles, his audience enwrapped as he once more

It is Manchester who have given us the highest accolade. It is Manchester whose approval I have looked to. And it is Manchester who has surely bestowed tonight's success. Friends we are victorious! And at once DICKENS and COLLINS playing, a madcap, joyful duet. MISS SABINE hovering close by. Yet DICKENS too busy for anyone is lost in fun, playing on with COLLINS as all break into lively spontaneous dancing. MAMEY and KATEY, GEORGINA HOGARTH in the mix. MR LEMON scoops up NELLY in passing. NELLY laughing, lost in a mad dance with MARIA and OTHERS. DICKENS, knocking back another drink, foot silently tapping against the floor, quietly revelling. His eyes briefly meet with NELLY, both lost in the sheer joy of it all.
15 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 21. DICKENS suddenly stands, behind MR EGG, moving his arms and legs almost as if a puppet master with his puppet.
Come come, Augustus you must dance and have no notion of walking. Mr EGG reluctantly concedes as DICKENS forces him, gaily onto the dance floor.
The ENTIRE COMPANY gathered around the piano. BERGER play Three Fishes as they sing. DICKENS at the heart, enjoying company in full song.

NELLY stands to one side of the room, flushed and exhausted. DICKENS stands performing some kind of mesmerizing/ hypnosis trick on MISS SABINE who sits opposite DICKENS, making the room still as he works with MISS SABINE
Now raise your arms Miss Sabine. Very slowly. MISS SABINE raises her arms, all compelled to watch.
It is remarkable. NELLY looks up, sees CATHERINE, standing on the periphery.
(with a smile) One of his magic tricks. CATHERINE’s eyes graze over NELLY, letting an awkward silence hang- CATHERINE (CONT’D) You are an admirer of my husband's work, Miss Ternan?
(nods ) Yes of course. At the moment I am lost in Little Dorrit. It has a darker heart perhaps. Though I am gripped between laughter and heartbreak. (MORE )
16 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 22.

Until now I thought Bleak House was the novel that would stay with me the most. It has this alarming spirit of unease. Lady Deadlock haunted by her past..I am drawn back to those pages again and again. And yet there is so much that also makes me smile.
It is a fiction designed to entertain.

No..no..surely it’s more than that. It makes us think. It changes us. CATHERINE considers NELLY, with thoughtful gaze then look back at DICKENS, a sudden heavy sadness overwhelming her which she deflects witha smile-
He will be up all night and cross all day. CATHERINE moves off, clearly heading to bed. CATHERINE (CONT’D) Good night, Miss Ternan.
Good night.
NELLY looks back at DICKENS, MISS SABINE now hypnotised and dancing a jig or the like, the party in uproar, DICKENS at the helm.

It is nearly dawn, the fire is low and the gas lamps now out. DICKENS sunk amongst the company of ACTORS; some dozing, some listening enwrapped, some searching the wine bottles for the last dregs of wine. MRS TERNAN wide eyed is now being mesmerised by DICKENS.
There are too many cats..too many cats and not enough birds.. I need wings. (MORE )
Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 23.

Hold the baby..hold the baby..No..No..She has gone...With no wings..Where is she?..Where is she?..Is she safe?...Please tell me she is safe. MRS TERNAN transfixed, her face etched with shock and ter the whole room held, watching her. DICKENS smiles, a litt uneasy.
Ah- DICKENS smiles, unsure, then he squeezes MRS TERNAN’s hands, releasing her back to reality.
And now you are back with us, Mrs Ternan. MRS TERNAN coming to, exhales.
I am back where? MARIA grips her hands, close to her.
Mother..Mother..I think you remembered Fanny. On the boat.
What did I say?
(close to) You were trying to save her, mother.
I am sorry Mr Dickens. I think I have strayed into some family history.
Indeed? The whole COMPANY leaning forward, listening, unsure wher this is leading-
My eldest daughter Fanny was thrown from her cot when my husband and I were touring in America some years ago. (MORE )
Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 24.
We were on a paddle steamer which was rammed by another boat. She was saved, miraculously between two mattresses.
The angels were watching.
They were. DICKENS moved by the closeness of these women, together, smiling at MRS TERNAN. She relaxes.
I am done Mr Dickens. MRS TERNAN slightly thrown, gathering herself to stand.

As am I. An extraordinary story. COLLINS finishes up the last of the wine, steering himsel wearily to bed, picking up his shoes and jacket on route- COLLINS (CONT’D) Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow. COLLINS pats DICKENS back affectionately in passing- COLLINS (CONT’D) Good night. The ACTORS stagger off to bed, a sense of good nights all round.
Five o’clock. Bed. NELLY lingers at the window. She pulls back the shutter, a thin shaft of dawn light searing through-
Good night- NELLY, MARIA and MRS TERNAN the last to leave.

You were quite wonderful tonight, Maria. (to all/ ie MARIA) I did try to console her in hushed aside but all she could whisper is ‘0! So sad. O! It is so sad!'Such a good pale little face.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 25. DICKENS cups MARIA’s face, kissing her gently on the forehead, a little drunk and heady from too much wine.
I am afraid I couldn’t stop the tears. You were too good.
You will not find a better Clara. MARIA smiles, following MRS TERNAN out-—

With every ounce of my soul, Mr Dickens.
We can barely carry them. DICKENS nods, oddly dishevelled, distracted tonight. He smiles at them all-  4l Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 52.
Thank you. Thank You..Goodness..I did not believe we would raise so much money...Where does one begin? DICKENS fingers lightly grazing the boxes, heavy with money, lined up on a table.
They will take some counting. He looks at NELLY, her smile quietly disarming him.
Yes..Yes.
Such an achievement.
We must celebrate.
Yes..Yes..We must.

head_text.subj: INT. DRAWING ROOM. TAVISTOCK HOUSE. LONDON. 1857. EVENING

text: A wide, drawing room, some furniture covered in dust shee DICKENS tentatively leading MRS TERNAN through the ghostl darkened landscape of Tavistock House.
You are moving in or out Mr Dickens? A dust sheet covering a grand piano and the occasional chair just visible in another room.
I am thinking of letting it. FANNY, NELLY and MARIA close behind, the collecting boxes being carried by DICKENS valet, JOHN, lugging boxes that puts on the floor.

My wife prefers to live outside of the public glare. London tires her and Gad’s Hill is where she likes to retreat with the children. NELLY takes in the silence, the endless emptiness, eviden in every room.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 53.
Gad’s Hill. Is that in Rochester-
(nods ) It is close. Walking distance.
Nelly was born in Rochester. DICKENS laughs, delighted at the coincidence, looking to NELLY.
I was schooled in Chatham.
Yes but my earliest memories are of Newcastle.
Newcastle I do not know so well. FANNY and MARIA taking in the room. FANNY turns, seeing DICKENS smiling at NELLY. MRS TERNAN peers through the window, out into the murky darkness-
Ah a garden. A grand piano, covered in a dust sheet, NELLY pulls a cor aside to reveal dusty keys. LIPS CLOSE to an ivory key, s blows-—
(leading her) Would you like to see it? MRS TERNAN laughs, DICKENS leading her out.
(following him) It is getting dark.
Come..Come. Let me show you. DICKENS leads MRS TERNAN out, leaving FANNY, MARIA and NE
He always seems so alone.
Yes.  42 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 54. NELLY presses down on a piano key, testing the note, caug on a repetitive middle c-
(hushed) It is like a mausoleum. On NELLY watching DICKENS leading MRS TERNAN around a darkened garden.

location: DRAWING ROOM. TAVISTOCK HOUSE. LONDON. 1857. NIGHT 4

text: NELLY caught peering at DICKENS desk; meticulously laid out papers, manuscripts and pencils, sharpened and in a row.
(calling back) Nelly- MRS TERNAN, MARIA and FANNY preparing to leave, standing in a distant hallway. DICKENS hovers, considering the many boxes now lined up on the floor.
We must leave you. Fanny has an audition in the morning and must rest her voice.
Yes of course yes.
We have a wager on how much was collected. I think five hundred but Fanny thinks-
More..More.. DICKENS smiles, making his goodbyes as they reach for gloves and coats, pulling them on as they head towards the door.
I will count them right away. They must be banked tomorrow.
You will be up all night.
I don’t sleep well anyway.  43 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 55.
We could help you. Together it will take us no time.
You have rehearsal in the morning, Nelly.
Nelly and I will stay and help Mr Dickens. If he does not object.
Well..No..I..thank you.
Mama- MRS TERNAN offers firm gaze, ushering FANNY and MARIA out
We shall not be late. FANNY disappearing out into the dark night looks back at NELLY, smiling reassuringly.
Good night.
Good night. The door closes-
DICKENS stands awkward, hovering, unsure what comes next.
Where shall we count them?
Yes..Yes..Through here (gesturing) Yes, through here. NELLY turns looking to MRS TERNAN but she ignores NELLY, following DICKENS through.

A snaking line of coins piled into small pillars on a table-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 56. NELLY and DICKENS lost in counting facing one another. Th whisper to one another, MRS TERNAN snoozes in a chair clo by-
Fourteen hundred and ninety eight,fourteen hundred and ninety nine..two shillings and tuppence. NELLY finishes counting triumphant.
Nearly one thousand five hundred pounds.
No?..Really.. They laugh. Triumphant.
We are rich...
Yes.
They will be delighted...Until the next time. DICKENS scoops up the money, easing it back into the boxes in piles.
(sudden) Do you like this life?
Well - it is not always of my own making but- NELLY waits. DICKENS silent, cutting himself off.
I don’t think I would. Being so constantly on show, so constantly watched.
I have my work. It is a great foil. They try but they cannot always find you there.
They?  44 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 57.
The hawkers. The men who need to make money. Who look to trip you up. And then there are the admirers. Those who wish you to be more than you can possibly be.
And what is that?
Good...I suppose. DICKENS smiles, caught out, looking away.

Later - on MRS TERNAN still asleep. Flickering candlelight- NELLY and DICKENS sharing a picnic supper perched at a cooks table. A half open bottle of wine, the remains of a make shift supper. CLOSE on DICKENS-
My father was sent toa debtor’s prison when I was twelve. I worked in a blacking factory thereafter, sealing bottles,sticking labels. (beat) It was hateful.
You were fond of your father?
He was my first audience. I honed my comic lines on him. DICKENS spoons the last mouthful of eggs, caught out.
You are too good at this. I have told you too much. You, now. You.
No really..There is little to tell.. (conceding) My father - An actor. Son of a Dublin grocer. Also in debt. (MORE )
Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 58.

Also dead. When I was seven. In an asylum. Mother never talks about it. I had a brother. He died at 10 months. Though how a boy would have fit with three girls. We are as thick as thieves. NELLY looks to MRS TERNAN.
She is devoted to us. Our life is unpredictable. NELLY aware of DICKENS concentration on her.
You are- DICKENS laughs, relishing NELLY.
What?
You are so free.
And you are not.

I dream sometimes that there is a place where no-one knows who I am, or asks me what I think, or even cares for my opinion. Somewhere..where I can just...live...heart beating...chest rising..Just breathe. DICKENS flushes, deflects, topping up his glass. The mood suddenly sombre-
It is late. She will sleep all night if we leave her. NELLY peers through MRS TERNAN still asleep in a chair.
Of course. I will ask John to bring the carriage round- DICKENS makes to go, suddenly something makes him stop.  45 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 59.
Tell me a secret.
What kind of secret?
Anything..Something.. Something you have never told anyone or perhaps never thought of telling.
(beat) My middle name is ‘Lawless’. (beat) Now your turn. What is your secret?
Ellen Lawless Ternan. That is my secret. They hold each others gaze. SUDDENLY beyond MRS TERNAN st the moment broken, her eyes opening.

NELLY, stiff in bonnet and corset, walking across the san BENHAM by her side. They have been walking in silence for some time. The grey wash of sea beyond, lapping at their boots as they walk, faces flushed, pressed to the wind.
I like to search for faces amongst the patterns in the sand.
And do you find them?
Sometimes. Mostly monsters and angels. BENHAM smiles, NELLY smiles. The DRAG of a FISHING BOAT crossing their paths. They navigate their way past the FISHERMAN pulling the boat across the sand.
So I thought Great Expectations might be a choice for our readings. David Copperfield is of course a contender but Great Expectations wins out for me in the end.
Very good.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 60.
Do you agree?
It is a fine novel. OTHER FISHERMAN and a FISHERWOMAN sit knotting nets. They walk on, BENHAM silent, her steady, calm companion, yet noting her distraction.

Mrs Wharton Robinson... Forgive me if I am intruding but...I see you are so often...distracted..There is some..As if a part of you is... absent. I do not wish to intrude. You talk I am sure to your husband-
No- A COUPLE pass, part of the ebb and flow of life, walking another direction, NELLY nods, in brief greeting, waverin momentarily, waiting for them to pass.
Not all wives do..To confide in the person you love the most..Sometimes that is hard.
George is a good man. A very good man.
Of course. NELLY lost deep within herself.
But you are troubled.
It comes and then it goes but it returns. I wish to help you...I hope I can be someone you can trust.
Really. I am quite well.
You are not.  46 47 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 61.
Please, Mr Benham...
I will listen without judgement. NELLY turns, looks at BENHAM, the grey scene beyond.
Dawn- NELLY waking listening to distant, muffled conversation. Reaching for her nightgown, NELLY pulls it across her shoulders, slipping out of bed. MARIA, sleeping by her si barely stirs.
NELLY’s bare feet walking down the stairs. Beyond the doo ajar, MRS TERNAN and FANNY in another room, locked in hea debate.
She is barely 18.

I have never had to concern myself with regard to you or Maria. There is always another tour for you and your younger sister..Mr. Buckstone has already enquired if Maria might be free for Pantomime. But Nelly...Nelly is different. I love her. I love her dearly but - her talent lies elsewhere. Charles Dickens is not merely some opportunist, some adventurer. I am thinking of what life will offer her. I am thinking of her future.
But what future would that be, mother?

Our profession is hard enough. You do not give it up. It gives you up. MRS TERNAN suddenly stops mid sentence, seeing NELLY, standing in the doorway, hearing all.  48 49 50 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 62.

location: OUTSIDE TOILET. YARD. PARK COTTAGE. 1857. DAWN. 48

text: NELLY sits on the toilet, head sunk in her hand. Blotting tears with a piece of ripped up news paper- Footsteps- NELLY furiously scrunches up the paper, wiping away her tears, ignoring the tap at the door.
Go away Fanny.
FANNY sinks down on a flower pot, outside the toilet door
I will stay here all day if I have to. (beat) Nelly-
NELLY, devastated-
I am a terrible actress. It is true. Please do not lie. NELLY stands, her forehead against the cool of the door.
Nelly, you are the truest person I know in life. But you are not an actress. NELLY closes her eyes stung, but oddly resigned.
Did no one think of telling me?
Nelly-
You have clearly discussed it. What other arrangements have been made which I do not know about?
It is only because we care so.  51 52 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 63.
I will not be bought or sold, Fanny. Whatever it is...it is not that. NELLY fights back the last furious tears-
Do you love him? NELLY’s eyes open, her face betraying all-
He is married-
FANNY, hands pressed to the door, hesitating-
That has not stopped him falling in love with you.
The door slowly opens, NELLY, face stained with tears, pe around. FANNY smiles, rubbing a blot of ink on NELLY’s no with her thumb.
(eyeing inky nose) You have the prime minster all over your nose. CLOSE UP ON NELLY, the pain of hearing this truth, yet smiling with affection for her FANNY-
CLOSE UP ON NELLY the same look of pain- with BENHAM once more on the beach, looking out at a YOUNG MAN and his SON flying a kite far off-
I was an actress.
An actress.

Not a very good one. (beat) My husband has indulged my interest in the theatre but he is ignorant of my past.  53 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 64. NELLY looks to BENHAM, hovering on telling him.
It is hard to reconcile this with life as the wife of a headmaster. So I have hidden it. A BOY far off with his FATHER in the rock pools.

I was not a child when I met Mr Dickens. I was eighteen. George believes I am considerably younger than I am. BENHAM stares, with sudden comprehension.NELLY stops. The cliffs fierce and towering behind them. The ocean in fron
He knows nothing of the depth of my affection.. (beat) My former affection for Mr Dickens.
I see. BENHAM hesitates, a seeping realisation evident in his ey
You will never tell your husband. She looks out at the grey churning sea.
He must never know. Never. BENHAM, listening intently, yet giving nothing away. She turns, looks at him.
Mr Benham, I have such remorse.
Spring- NELLY, eyes closed, surrounded by flowers, a birthday cake held in front of her-
Open your eyes. MARIA, FANNY, MRS TERNAN, the FLIGHTY ACTRESS and OTHERS Cheers as NELLY blows out the candles. A beautiful house just visible beyond-  54 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 65.
Happy Birthday, darling.
Happy birthday..Happy Birthday.

Maria, is it raisin? MARIA smiles, NELLY smothers her in kisses, excited and excitable, twirling across the grass. A distant rap at the door- NELLY absorbed, opening presents. A few moments later a MAID appears.

(to NELLY) Miss Ellen, Mrs Dickens to see you. NELLY’s face falls, the noise of the party hushes to a still- FANNY and MARIA look to one another. MRS TERNAN goes to greet her, NELLY gently stops her. NELLY heads inside leaving behind the chaotic party, lazy on the grass-
CATHERINE DICKENS standing in the parlour, oddly fragile, rouge dotting her pale cheeks. She turns on seeing NELLY standing in the doorway.
I thought this was the right house... NELLY enters, plumping a cushion on a seat, and offering it in gesture.
Please. Won’t you sit down? CATHERINE, eyes silently tracing over the pretty sitting room, eyes alighting on a series of tiny prints of costumes hung on the wall.

I had heard he had found you somewhere close on the square- CATHERINE peers closer.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 66. CATHERINE (CONT’D) (peering closer) Such attention to detail. NELLY follows CATHERINE’s gaze-
It is all just paste and glass. Outside, distant whoops and laughter-
You find us in disarray. NELLY nods towards half packed cases.
My mother and sister Frances are to go to Italy. My sister is to be a governess to the Trollope family.
Really?
Mr Dickens has kindly made the introduction. He has been more than charitable to my family. CATHERINE nods, considering NELLY, with cool resignation.

My husband has always been very generous. CATHERINE holds out a small velvet box to NELLY- CATHERINE (CONT’D) Happy Birthday Miss Ternan. NELLY takes it, with surprise, flushing. A game of musical chairs or the like just visible playing out in the garden- CATHERINE (CONT’D) Won't you open it? NELLY hesitates, looking down at the box in her hand, tentatively fingering the paper. CATHERINE (CONT’D) It is a gift from Charles. It was mistakenly delivered to me.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 67. NELLY, inwardly reeling, carefully unpeels the paper, tearing it a little- CATHERINE (CONT’D) The jewellers naturally believing- Opening it, her breath catches on seeing- A beautiful bracelet, embedded with deep red Rubies- CATHERINE (CONT’D) Charles was eager that I ensure it found its way to its rightful recipient. NELLY, catches on this, embarrassed by such obvious cruelty from DICKENS- CATHERINE (CONT’D) He is fond of you. NELLY flushes-— CATHERINE (CONT’D) And you of him? NELLY hesitates- CATHERINE (CONT’D) That is a silly question. He is Mr Charles Dickens. .Even in those early years together even I could not fail to be impressed. But you will find, you must share him with his public. They will be the constant and in truth you will never absolutely know which one he loves the most. You or them. I do not believe he knows himself. But they will not give him up, of that you can be sure, Miss Ternan. They will love him beyond the grave. (close to) Will you love him as long? (beat) I am interrupting your party. CATHERINE, making to stand, nods, holding NELLY with quiet passive scrutiny.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 68. CATHERINE (CONT’D) Charley said you were not that pretty. I could not remember but I see now my son was being kind to me.
I am really far too old for parties. There is not a soul under twenty in attendance.
Well Charles should be here soon and he is nothing if not youthful. CATHERINE makes to go-
I wish you a very happy birthday. Far off the party in full swing.

The aftermath of the party, drained of GUESTS, the TERNAN family seated, sober after CATHERINE’s visit- NELLY, the ruby bracelet resting between her fingers,MARI and FANNY seated close by, unsettled. MARIA sketches, let the pencil suddenly still in her hand.- SUDDENLY COLLINS and DICKENS spill through the back gate moving into the house. DICKENS tracing his fingers along papered wall, peering at it with delight.
New paper on the wall?
Yes. Do you like it?
Very much..very much..You have made it home.
We have tried. It is a most beautiful house.
Isn’t it?
Thank you.  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 68A. DICKENS beams, COLLINS by his side, sensing all is not qu right.
And the chairs? New?
Yes-?
We are too late? Are we too late? NELLY snaps the box shut, hurrying to pocket it.
You have missed the cake. COLLINS snatches the last piece of cake off a table, positioned under a tree.
No, say it is not so. Have we missed all the fun? DICKENS standing with COLLINS both dressed in party hats and beaming, a tension puncturing their fun.
We had hoped you would provide it.  56 57 58 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 69.

There is only one thing for it. We will have to whisk her away. NELLY scoops up a stray ribbon, wrapping it around her finger, busying herself as she walks back to the house, passing DICKENS. He gently stops her, a hand on her arm, quizzical as she refuses to meet his gaze.
Say you will come? On NELLY, caught in the conflict of feelings. MRS TERNAN, MARIA and FANNY looking on.
NELLY squeezed between DICKENS and COLLINS, being quietly led-
Where are we going? DICKENS smiles, heady and happy, NELLY concedes, a growing fury bubbling underneath.
You shall see.
COLLINS pulling off his coat, NELLY and DICKENS close behind, showing them in-
Come through..Come through. NELLY looks to DICKENS confused. A pair of ladies shoes- A ladies coat- Several hats resting on a hat stand. NELLY’s eyes grazing over them with bemused curiosity-

location: DRAWING ROOM. COLLINS HOUSE. LONDON. 1858. NIGHT. 58

text: A pretty drawing room- CAROLINE GRAVES [late 20's] handsome and flushed, yet in delicate informal negligee, already coming through, greeting DICKENS warmly-  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 70.
Wilkie, why did you not say? COLLINS kisses CAROLINE, brief yet betraying an intimacy, that unsettles NELLY.
We are celebrating a very special birthday.
Caroline may I present Miss Ellen Ternan.
It is her birthday today! CAROLINE greets NELLY warmly, hands cupping hers in greeting-
Happy Birthday. I have heard only good things. NELLY looks to DICKENS, not quite comprehending. DICKENS quickly looks away, deflects, peering at a picture on the wall.
Caroline a new painting? Quite slap up. Is the Butler about-?
Yes..Yes..She is about..Here she is.. (moving off) I shall find wine! HARRIET GRAVES, CAROLINE’s daughter [5 yrs] comes rushing in, in night gown-
My but she squeals-— DICKENS scoops HARRIET up, swinging her in his arms-
May I take your wrap and gloves?
Thank you. But I prefer to keep them on. CAROLINE, swallows silent affront, gesturing for NELLY to sit-  59 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 71.
What a lovely home.

Yes..Yes..Wilkie found it.. INT. DRAWING ROOM. COLLINS’ HOUSE. LONDON. 1858. NIGHT. 5 Distant laughter and screams-— CAROLINE and NELLY sit alone, in awkward silence. CHARLES, COLLINS and HARRIET lost somewhere deep within the house.
Charles christened her ‘the butler’ on their first meeting. Distant squeals, DICKENS just audible, lost in raucous game.
It is all a game with him. (beat) She is very dear. NELLY looks away, quietly wanting to put distance between her and CAROLINE.

Does this offend you Miss Ternan? (silence) Wilkie despises marriage and as a widow it suits me well. We live very happily. (silence) But you do disapprove I see. We have fallen in love with men of standing, Miss Ternan-
I am not in love. Squeals of delight- HARRIET rushing in DICKENS fast on her tail, collapsing into a heap on a faded chaise-
(sudden) It is late. Really...It is too too late. I must leave. Please excuse me Miss Graves. DICKENS sobering, hearing the urgency in NELLY’s voice-  60 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 72.
Nelly-? INT. CARRIAGE. NEAR AMPTHILL SQUARE. LONDON.
NELLY silent, DICKENS close by her side-
And still she is silent- NELLY reaches out to open the carriage door, drawing to a still. DICKENS reaches out for NELLY, stiffening on his touch-
Mr Buckstone has offered me The World and The Stage. It has a ridiculous plot. A titled lady saved from debt by her sister, an actress.
But a very amusing final scene.
It was you that secured me the role. DICKENS hesitates, NELLY sees in his silence, that it was.
And did you mean to deliberately humiliate me tonight?
You did not like Miss Graves?
You expect me to associate with a woman living so openly with Mr Collins outside of marriage? Entertaining guests as if she were-
Nelly-

I do not wish to appear ungrateful. You have been generous, some might say too generous to my family. But I did not realise that I was to be your whore.  61 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 73. DICKENS, floundering-
DICKENS hurries after NELLY, fumbling in her clutchbag.
Nelly- NELLY, tear stained and bereft, holds out the bracelet box to DICKENS-
It was a mistake- DICKENS reluctantly takes the box. NELLY searches in her bag for her key.
Did you send Catherine to me?
Yes.
How could you be so cruel to her? DICKENS wavers, yet remains silent.
She is the mother of your children.
And for that I will always be grateful but I do not love her.
But why-? NELLY’s eyes search with genuine despair.

She understands nothing. She sees nothing. I thought if she saw you she would understand that I have nothing with her. I wanted her to see it. DICKENS, consumed by a fury, NELLY shocked, by the volcanic passion.  62 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 74.

It? What is it, Charles? What is it that we are? Would you call us friends? Perhaps we are friends.We listen to one another as if we were. You have been kind..so kind to my family..A friend...And yet you do not feel like a friend. DICKENS stills her hands, cupping her fingers clasping the key.
And when your wife asked me...when she asked me if I was fond of you... I could not honestly reply. I wanted to say ‘No’- A POLICE OFFICER passing, drawn by the noise.
Can I be of assistance Sir? DICKENS offers a half smile of reassurance to the POLICE OFFICER.
Is this young lady troubling you, Sir?
No..No..Thank you..She is not troubling me at all. All is well. The POLICE OFFICER nods, moving on- They stand in silence by the door, DICKENS’ hand still resting on NELLY, the key in the lock.
May I come in? (silence) Nelly-?
DICKENS and NELLY sit in silence, across the room from one another, NELLY’s quiet fury sobered now. Yet neither able to make a move. A lamp lit low the only light.  63

Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 75. A vein in DICKENS’ temple pulsing, lost in some deep internal conflict which he cannot speak of, a deep inner consultation of the self until- The PRESS of a floorboard overhead. They both look up, hearts catching in their chests. A cough. MRS TERNAN rolling over in bed. The house once more falls silent.

It is late. NELLY nods, makes to stand. DICKENS stands. They look at one another, NELLY makes to show him out. At once he catches her hand, leaning into her, his forehead pressed to hers. NELLY hesitant, sees the despair flickering, in DICKENS face. NELLY’s eyes meet his. They stand, close, lips not yet meeting, breath warm, held in one another’s gaze, lost in silent communion until- DICKENS leans into NELLY, head bowed, his forehead close to her cheek, his body almost buckling. NELLY eases her arms around him, holding him in almost rocking embrace. His fingers intertwine with hers- CLOSE UP ON their hands, intertwined, tentatively exploring, finding one another in these tiny flickering moments of silent physical connection. On NELLY, CLOSE UP, in her face all the conflicting emotions, their lips almost meeting, the barest whisper of a kiss. They stand, entwined and silent-

DICKENS standing with a CARPENTER who is putting shelving and a partition between the dressing room and CATHERINE a DICKENS bedroom. He turns, CATHERINE staring at him, he looks at her with quiet, remorseless gaze.
The crown of a hill, DICKENS just visible head,, NELLY hurrying to keep up, they are lost in conversation. We ar behind them.
...I would walk from the Aldwych to Camden to Highgate then back to Westminster and then on to Millbank.  64 65 66 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 76.
You have London in your blood.
Alright? NELLY nods, breathless yet exhilarated.
Yes. Yes-
I walk at quite a pace. Their feet walking on.
NELLY walking, boots sinking in the sand- A tiny figure etched across the sand, a dot amidst the vastness of the landscape. INT. CARRIAGE. TRAIN. NEAR STAPLEHURST. KENT. DAY. 1865.
The TEARING STEADY RHYTHM OF TRAIN WHEELS AGAINST STEEL A
The STREAK of countryside, FLEETING and ABSTRACTED, a BLU light and colour beyond. Then just visible in the glass, NELLY’s reflection indist yet rippling in the glass-

head_text.subj: A SHADOWY FIGURE OF A MAN CAUGHT IN THE GLASS OPPOSITE HE

text: Dawn- NELLY and DICKENS just visible walking through the early morning fog, lost in conversation. NELLY strides ahead, turning, holding out a hand pulling him up the hill-
Father- CHARLEY DICKENS, books in hand, stops in surprise, eyes falling briefly on NELLY, with quiet recognition.
Charley, what are you doing here?  Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 77.
I walk this way, if I have taken the earlier train-
You remember Miss Ternan-? CHARLEY nods to NELLY in greeting, stiffening a little.
Of course.
Charley, how are you? You look well.
I am.
Charley is working in the city.
How very clever.
Not really. A friend of father’s.
You are well?
Quite well. Thank you Miss Ternan.
I still have the glove. NELLY holds up her gloved hands with a smile.
..-which you rescued for me. I would have been most unhappy to have lost it. They are my favourite pair.

I am sure you would have found another. Perhaps not of equal colour or quality but easy enough to pick up- NELLY stung, DICKENS fury evident in his face. NELLY deflects, saving face-  67 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 78.
We were about to take breakfast. Will you join us?
Thank you. I am already late. CHARLEY raises his hat to NELLY, moving swiftly on. Suddenly he stops-—
Father. (beat) Will we see you at home? DICKENS silent. CHARLEY continues his journey along the path. DICKENS and NELLY together, yet oddly separate.
A beautiful summers day- DICKENS family enjoy a garden party, playing mad three legged races on the lawn, orchestrated by DICKENS, who stands caught between reading a newspaper and watching th race.

Faster Plorn. Faster. You keep letting everyone else win. The extra leg is there to add to your speed. CATHERINE sits close by drinking tea. GEORGINA seated clo by. DICKENS clutches a newspaper in his hand which he slams d infuriated.
You could not keep it quiet forever, Charles. CATHERINE pours herself some tea, looking at DICKENS with distracted concern. CATHERINE (CONT’D) No matter. You must deny it.
Rumour can always be denied. We will host Christmas here. Invite everyone we know. Do not worry.  68 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 79.
And then you must stop this. DICKENS stiffens.
But what if I do not want to?
Don’t be foolish. You cannot keep her a secret. Hiding her hurt, CATHERINE withdraws her hand, caught between affection and furious despair. He turns holding h look with direct intent.
Yes I can.

location: DRAWING ROOM GADS HILL. KENT. 1858. DAY. 68

text: The squeak of tin wheels-—

I can’t read it. Will you read it. Through a door, PLORN pushing a toy train along the floor looks up, watching- CHARLEY takes a copy of a newspaper from CATHERINE who si silent and stiff on a chair. He silently braces himself, reading aloud.

There is some domestic trouble of mine, long standing, on which I will make no further remark it being of a sacredly private nature. However-— CATHERINE turns, a look of shocked despair flickering across her face as she sees PLORN peering through the doorway.

.-it has lately been brought to an arrangement, which involves no anger or ill-will of any kind. My wife Catherine and I have decided to separate. The headline on the newspaper now clear - CHARLES DICKENS SEPARATES FROM WIFE.  69 70 Blue Revisions dated 11th June 2012 80.

The whole origin, progress and surrounding circumstances have been throughout, within the knowledge of my children. The SQUEAK SQUEAK of the tin train just audible as he wheels it away, disappearing along a distant corridor.
It is amicably composed, and its details have but to be forgotten by those concerned in it.
NELLY knelt, repotting plants. Looking up to see MARIA, o the approach, pulling off her bonnet and hat en route, holding up a newspaper

I most solemnly declare that all the lately whispered rumors touching upon my association with a certain young lady are abominably false.
